description.text:
This is a handle for an M3 allen key to have a better grip and make more torque.
To print this you have to pause the print when it is about to close the slot fo the allen key, you can tell because there is a square on the top right corner of the slot for the last 2 layers or so. Put the allen key in and resume the print.
If you want you can use the model version w/support to support the key so that is doesnt fall off the slot while printing.

This is my new 4GB USB Memory ... Android! This thing is designed around a 4GB Kingston USB Stick cause it is cheap. Maybe others work too, but i've only experience with this one. My printed parts fitted quite good, but maybe thats just on my machine.
Feedback would be great! Made with Freecad and Blender. If you make one, please send me a picture... i love pictures ;) Portions of this page are modifications based on work created and shared by Google and used according to terms described in the Creative Commons 3.0 Attribution License.

I've put up a picture for every step, so this shouldn't be to hard. 1 - You will need a Kingston Data Traveler G3 USB Stick. This one is the 4GB Version
but others should work too. Printed Parts: 1x Holder(Holder.stl), 1x Body and
Head. 2 - First you need the USB Memory Stick. 3 - Open it. I used my Dremel like tool and a screwdriver to crack it up. Take care
not to destroy the electonics! 4 - Get your printed Memory Holder. 5 - Put the Electronics in it. I used a Hot glue gun to fix the electronics onto the
holder. 6 - Take your Android's Body and put the Holder in it. This can be tricky cause
the Parts are designed to fit tight. Use a Dremel or other tools if you can't
get it in. Best to try this without electronics first! 7 - Body fully assambled. 8 - Take your Android's head and put it on the Body to complete him! 9 - Have fun with him! PS: I am not responsible if you Break your USB Stick!

author: TaranUA

description.text:
I was tired of all the little nylon spacers which get lost and are a pain to line up, so I designed and printed some spacer plates. The front is flush with the front of the CF plates to keep them from getting dirt in between and hopefully prevent anything from peeling the plates back. The middle spacer I made one large piece so that it's easier to index the holes. The rear spacer I turned into a LED bumper mount. Its 100mm wide so it fits 2 sections of the strips that are common(I bought a long roll on ebay that has 3 LEDs per 50mm section).

These are 3mm thick by default. I included a set of 4mm thick parts per user request.

comments.text:
Use RepetierHost or a similar program with which you can control the printer directly.
1) move the reference points with G28 and adjust the table manually with a straight paper sheet
2) once again G28
3) is next G92 Z10
4) move in 0.1mm step down the heating bed until the paper tweaks at the nozzle
5) calculate the value on display or software for example (10mm - 9.2) = 0.8
The calculated value you enter here in the frimware at the line (#define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -0.8)
6) Firmware flash
7) have fun;)

title: Lasercut Ikea Kallax or Expedit 2x13x13 Stackable Tray for 2x2 Tiles
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Half-pint sibling to my extreme deep-dish storage solution (4" x13" x 13") for game tiles or other collections (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2219928), which fits neatly into my previously published Ikea Expedit or Kallax storage shelf/bookcase trays. Designed for easy carrying and to hold modest amounts of weight. The provided templates (two pages) have a blank space that you might fill with other cutting patterns and are designed with a minimum 0.5" safety margin around edge of the frame. You can customize them at your own leisure with labels and text as demonstrated in the pictures provided. (I am not promoting one set of dungeon tiles tiles over the other, just printing the ones I have paid for). Depending on the divider configuration you choose, this tray will hold up to eighteen dozen 2" x 2" tiles or 36 models or structures no larger than 2 inches on any side. If you leave out the odd divider you can stack 2x4 tiles instead.

Formatted for cutting on two 3mm MDF cut from (Arch C) 24" x 18" sized sheets, which each fit across the bed of an Epilog Helix. I have provided the PDF and a SVG files that I converted online at https://cloudconvert.com/vsd-to-svg. Shared as is.

If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises. And if you download this, please LIKE, it helps get the word out and spread these designs around. That is all.

author: teeoff138

title: K1S Dashcam LCD Mount with Tilt Adjustment

description.text:
This is an adjustable mounting bracket for the Koonlung K1S Dashcam LCD Monitor, and is designed to fit the mounting clip supplied with the K1S LCD unit (the LCD just slots onto this bracket, for easy fitting/removal). The base is 60mm diameter and can be fixed using 2mm double-sided tape (for example: 3M 9448A). It allows for tilt adjustment on two axes (elevation and roll) so that you can level the LCD, even on a sloping dash.

Requires 2x M3 countersunk screws and nuts to assemble the three parts. In my case, I added double sided tape between the parts before tightening the screws, to semi-permanently fix it at the right angle.

I've since tidied up the wiring with some 90 degree right-angle micro USB extension cables.

Obviously this gets subjected to extremes of temperature in a car window, so it's probably best to print in ABS rather than PLA.

description.text:
I wanted to make some custom shwings, which are wings that people put on shoes when they run.

I wanted them to be Brinton Elementary colors, so I drew this up and just changed the filament partway through. Enjoy and GO GO GO!!!

Resolution:

0.1

Notes:

Make sure to print at 0.1mm and change the filament color after the second layer is done.

Also make sure your first layer height isn't set to 0.2 or 0.3 (then you'd have one layer which would probably break apart more easily)

Just a quick test so you can compare the strengths of a model.

Made with a Ultimaker 2 in mind, should be ok to print in any 0.4mm diameter nozzle setup.

This is a simple Filament holder, really simple.

After printint, you will also need:

  • Threaded bar
  • 4 nuts
  • 2 bearings.
  • Barbecue stick (yeap :] )

As you can see in the pictures, just use the stick to join the two pieces of the holder, and create a "free spinning bar" using the metal hardware pieces, and place the bearing on the top, this will stay in place as the filament is used, but still very easy to take off and exchange the roll.

Printer:

Kossel Mini

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Top pieces: 0.2 layer height
Base pieces: 0.3 layer height
Connector: 0.3 layer height

After printing, you will need to glue all pieces together. There are holes in the two main pieces used to place the connector pieces (2x), and help in the process.

The top piece is printed separately to get a better finish, you can print it at 0.2 layer height, and the base ate 0.3; this works very fine.

This piece was designed in OnShape online CAD application.

Feel free to take a look and make your own copy of this.

To access the project go to: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/dbaeafe8cbefdba9659edb56/w/94474ab31a2bcdb75417d43c/e/1b77a62ebf48b2ce148ffcf6

title: PopLite Coffee Roaster
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is the beginning of a project to convert a PopLite popcorn popper, model #0486001 (1440watts), into a coffee roaster. I'll continue to post parts, build instructions and pictures here as it comes together.

The glass tube is a "Pyrex Bake-A-Round Bread Loaf Mold Baking Tube" I purchased on Ebay. You can also find them on Etsy for $15 - $20. The can was a re-fried bean can with a 101mm OD that fits perfectly inside the screws.

Remaining to do is a control box for an Arduino UNO R3 and SSR to control the AC power and fan speed as well as read a couple of thermal couples for PID.

I also need to make an aluminum funnel inside the roasting chamber to make the coffee side down to the hot air jet at a better angle. Another re-fried bean can and some steel screen will cover the top for a chafe catcher.

UPDATE:
I posted two parts that make up a valve to control air flow from a mini shopvac. Make sure to break out the two areas of grillwork in the center piece. They break easily when printed with PLA and will blow up into the heater of they fail while you are roasting to create a really big mess - trust me!
Run a length of shopvac from the vaccum output to the valve, then from the value output (the longer side of the Y) into the blower base. By using two hoses, you can get vaccum father away and maybe hear 1st crack over the blower sounds.

To figure out how much coffee you can roast, turn the power off on the roaster/heater and turn on the blower/vacuum. Add green beans slowly until just before they stop circulating. When you turn on the heater, the impeller will add a little more lift.

Here is a Youtube video of the roaster in action on my back porch. I didn't have a chafe catcher at this point so was relegated to roasting outdoors.

Printer:

ANet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

This is PLA. It isn't directly exposed to the heat of the roaster so it should be safe.

comments.text: whoa this thing is cool! I'd love to see a video of a roast if you've got one!

title: Molle / PALS speed clip 3, 5 and 7 loops

description.text:
Molle sticks / speed clips in 3, 5 and 7 loop sizes. For attaching accessories to Molle / PALS webbing.

There are two versions "tough" and "light" of each size.

There is an experimental version of the 3 loop TOUGH version in an attempt to make it stronger following comments.

Designed to print flat-side down with bed-support (that's what the hole is for).

If using ABS - print with dense support as it doesn't bridge well and you can get holes.

Please post photos of your makes - Its cool to see what you print + I like to learn how people's print settings affect my designs.

title: Lantian 90L frame parts (cam seat, runcam micro swift mount, xt30 mount, motor softmounts, FC softmount)

description.text:
Info: BG now offers taller spacers (22mm): https://www.banggood.com/4-PCS-Frame-Kit-Parts-Aluminum-Column-M2D3_522-for-Runcam-Swift-Mini-p-1198296.html
These will work without adding nuts to increase the height.

Update: I added a "love seat" style mount for the Micro Swift. You'll need to mount the camera with good doublesided tape. The frame height is not quite enough, so I used two M2 nuts to slightly raise the top plate. I also added a bit of thin double sided tape under the mount to make sure it stays put. This mount allows the use of full 2" props.

Update: I added a mount for the Runcam Micro Swift, in 2 variations. This camera is a VERY tight fit, I had to file down the corners of the lens mount a bit to make it fit at a good angle.
You will be limited to 1935 or shorter propellers and have to use countersunk screws (M2x4 or M2x5), otherwise the props will hit the mount.

Update:
Added a thinner, lighter XT30 mount to reduce weight and increase space from the prop edges to the mount.
Added slightly modified camera mount to bring it forward another 1-2mm to reduce the amount of frame edges visible due to the high FOV of these cams.

This is a complete set, mainly meant to be printed in TPU/TPE.

Cam mount fits the Eachine EF-02 and Boldclash cameras, just add a dab of glue to keep it from falling out. It's set at roughly 30°, but can be varied by holding the cam at a lower angle and glueing it then.

Motor softmounts are used beneath the motors, adding approx. 1 mm of height.

FC standoff is 3mm tall and acts both as spacer and anti-vibration mount.

XT30 mount requires a drop of glue on the XT30.

XT30 mount and cam seat are meant to be slid onto 4mm diameter aluminium spacers. The 90L frame (http://www.banggood.com/90L-90mm-Brushless-Micro-FPV-Racing-Frame-Carbon-Fiber-14g-p-1135513.html) comes with hex spacers. Order these with the frame instead: http://www.banggood.com/Eachine-Aurora-100-Mini-Brushless-FPV-Racer-Spare-Part-M2D3_520-Hexgonal-Column-4PCS-p-1135504.html

title: My (Medium) Weather iot Box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my second iot autonomous weather station.
This box is made for minimum sizing with a 2000 mAh for 6 month.

If you want a very small weather iot, you can also try this model :
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2027990

Hardware setup:

  • ESP8266 ESP-12F

  • USB Lithium Battery Charger Module Board With Charging And Protection

  • DHT22 AM2302 Digital Temperature Humidity Sensor

  • 26350 2000mAh 3.7V Rechargeable Li-ion Battery

Software setup:

To collect data for my Home Automation (Jeedom), I use Espeasy.
It allow to control you esp8266, and all module boards.

To allow 6 autonomous month, I send data to Jeedom every 20 minutes and activate the deepsleep process.

pinout:

3.3v output to VCC, EN (ch-pd), VIN (dht22)
Gnd output to GND and GPIO15, GND (dht22)
GPIO14 to data (dht22)
GPIO16 to RST (to allow deep sleep)
you can add a special external pinout to allow debug :
TX/RX/Ground to dupont wire
you can also add an external reset button :
RST and Gnd to switch

Printing:

You can download all 5 parts or just esp_waether1_all.stl for all part (exept debug).

On a recent trail run a couple people got separated from the group. Nobody was lost for long and we ended the run with some laughs and jokes about needing survival whistles... which is actually a good idea. Since our club is called the BATS I remixed this whistle with the club logo to make complimentary Bat-Whistles!
Minor filing (or just poking around with a paper clip) may be needed to clear out the airway of any stray filament for a clean sound.

Opened our club logo SVG in Inkscape. Selected the "bat" shape. Used the Paths to OpenSCAD extension to export the path to an extruded polygon. Edited the OpenSCAD file directly to import and superimpose the whistle model.

description.text:
This is a 1:150 scale model of the Palomar-Hale 200" telescope. The model can be scaled for printing at different scales. We printed it at 1.5x scale, which resulted in a 1:100 scale model. The model articulates.

This 3D model was created by the Observational Cosmology Laboratory at University of Illinois(http://obscos.astro.illinois.edu/) as part of a collection of teaching aids for demonstrating various types of telescope mounts and pointing.

The pillars should be glued down to a base. We used transparent grey acrylic.
More than one of some parts are needed. See exploded view for guidance.

More information can be found about Palomar Observatory at:
(http://www.astro.caltech.edu/palomar/about/telescopes/hale.html)

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Resolution:

Medium or High

Infill:

Users Preference, we used 20%

Notes:

This is a fairly complex model consisting of almost 20 parts. The most challenging part is the yoke.

If someone who wants to build this has questions on how to proceed, please contact the uploader and we will help you!

Painting

We painted some parts grey for a visual contrast. Otherwise, only light sanding was utilized as a finishing process.

Laser cut and spray painted ladders were added for more detail. These are not included here but are simple to make.

This model was made in SolidWorks using the generously provided 3D model created by Selden E.B. as a starting point. Several undergrad astronomy and physics students learned SolidWorks partially by helping recreate these parts.

Primary modeling/re-modeling was done by Robert.

remixed_from.author: OderWat
remixed_from.title: Anet A8 - Anti Z Wobbel TNG (Set)

title: Anet A8 Anti Z Wobbel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
He diseñado esta pieza partiendo de esta otra de OderWat,
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2067676 mis agradecimientos por ello.

Cuando subí el diseño de piezas superiores que atrapan el husillo del eje Z mediante rodamientos http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2192900 , no fueron pocos los que me comentaron que esa pieza sobraba, hay un debate sobre este tema, que creo es interesante. En mi opinión, creo que muchos confunden el husillo helicoidal de la Anet A8 con el viejo tornillo que venía en las primeras Prusa I3, ya que ese tornillo no tenía otra función que la de atornillar pero se utilizaba como husillo, causando mil problemas de desajustes. El husillo que viene en la Anet A8, por lo menos en mi caso, es de buena calidad, tanto como las barras del eje Z, no he apreciado deformaciones en los míos. Creo que el problema no es el husillo, el problema está por una parte en la difícil tarea de hacer que las diferentes piezas de los ejes Z caigan en la misma vertical, así como la holgura de la tuerca T. En cualquier caso, si se aprecian problemas como el famoso wobbel en las impresiones, quizás esta pieza pueda ser de utilidad, pero sin dejar de lado la revisión de toda la estructura de la impresora, ya que este problema o efectos parecidos se pueden generar por otros motivos, como por ejemplo tener las barras del eje X o Z con holgura en su sujeciones, etc, etc.

He tenido que rediseñar el original de Oderwat ya que en mi caso el hotend de mi impresora está colocado muy bajo, por lo que me deja muy poco espacio para colocar la pieza original. Con el diseño que he realizado este espacio se minimiza, además he incluido unas bolas a modo de rodamientos para que la fricción entre las dos piezas sea mínima, y así favorecer que las piezas que sustentan el extrusor tan solo tenga un movimiento vertical, ya que creo que con el peso del extrusor más el motor del eje X, sin estos “rodamientos” seguramente acompañen en los movimientos horizontales a la pieza de la tuerca T, causando efectos indeseables en la impresión.

Las bolas que he utilizado son de 6 mm, y los tornillos de 2,5 por 8 mm.

Printer:

Anet A8

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

80%

title: Tanker car for OS-Railway - fully 3D-printable railway system!

description.text:
This is a tanker-car for the OS-Railway concept.
Click here for the OS-Railway main page: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2146361

This car is based on the same bogies as the freight car chassis you can find in the following link: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2152351
But for convenience I've included all parts you need on this page so you don't have to download anything from there.

First look at the pre-assembled STL's called buildplate_something, but all parts are also included separately.

If you wonder why the main tank parts are rotated the way they are, it's to compensate for a not-perfectly-calibrated Z-axis. I noticed that at least the Prusa can suffer from a tilting Z-axis which will make the prints tilt. Even if it's a very tiny angle it will be amplified if a part is split in two and printed so that the angles adds to each other. If the parts are rotated 180 degrees compared to each other, the angles will take out each other and the tank will still be straight.

What you need:
6pcs M3x10
2pcs M3x10-12
8pcs M2x6
2pcs wheel axles 3mm x 42mm suggest carbon fiber
8pcs ball bearings 3mm id, 6mm od, 2,5mm width (or use the dummy PLA bearings included, they actually have a very low friction against carbon fiber but you may need to drill them out a bit to make the shafts turn loose. I actually used these on my prototypes to save ball bearings and this works way better than expected!)

Printer:

Prusa i3 mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Build plate 1 - bogies and misc parts
100% infill
no support
no raft
no skirt
0.1-0.2mm resolution is OK

Build plate 2 - main tank parts
100% infill
no support
no raft
skirt is needed! the parts have a very small footprint
0.25mm will produce OK result and reduce print time

Build plate 3 - tank ends
100% infill
Support from build plate
no raft
no skirt
Use as low layer height as you have time for, as the rounded angles will show the edges from the layers very visibly if you use thick layers. You can of course seal these steps if you sand and paint the tank for example.

Build plate 4 - wheels
100% infill
no support
no raft
no skirt
will be OK with 0,2mm layer height, but if you have time use 0,1mm.

Assembly

CA-glue works very well with PLA, especially the gel-type which is easier to use than the usual super-thin one.

Stat by gluing in the tank_connector into the tank piece that has a hole in the roof, and make sure that the connector ring don't block the hole for the tank cap insert. Then glue the two tank pieces together. The rest is hopefully self explanatory but don't hesitate to ask any question in the comments!
Designed using Fusion 360

author: Depronized

description.text:
Polygons and polyhedrons are the most powerful shapes available in OpenSCAD. However, it can sometimes be a challenge to construct them correctly. Consider this library to help you construct and work with your Polytopes..

Tools

module polytope_number (c, f, e, vi=true, fi=true, ei=true, sp=false, ts, th, to, tr=0)

  • Label the vertices, paths, and edges of a polytope.

module polytope_frame (c, f, e, vi=true, fi=true, ei=true, vc=1, fc=2, ec=0)

  • Assemble a polytope skeletal frame using child objects.

module polytope_bbox (c, f, a)

  • The 3d or 2d bounding box shape for a polytope.

Math Functions

function polytope_faces2edges (f)

  • List the edge coordinate index pairs of a polytope.

function polytope_limits (c, f, a, d=[0:2], s=true)

  • Determine the bounding limits of a polytope.

function polytope_bbox_pf (c, f, a)

  • Generate a bounding box polytope for another polytope in 3d or 2d.

function polytope_line (c, f, e, i, l, r=false)

  • Get a line from an edge or any two vetices of a polytope.

function polytope_vertex_av (f, i)

  • List the adjacent vertices for a given polytope vertex.

function polytope_vertex_af (f, i)

  • List the adjacent face indexes for a polytope vertex.

function polytope_edge_af (f, e, i)

  • List the adjacent face indexes for a polytope edge.

function polytope_vertex_n (c, f, i)

  • Get a normal vector for a polytope vertex.

function polytope_edge_n (c, f, e, i)

  • Get a normal vector for a polytope edge.

function polytope_face_n (c, f, i, l, cw=true)

  • Get the normal vector of a polytope face.

function polytope_face_m (c, f, i, l)

  • Get the mean coordinate of all vertices of a polytope face.

function polytope_face_mn (c, f, i, l, cw=true)

  • Get the mean coordinate and normal vector of a polytope face.

function polytope_plane (c, f, i, l, cw=true)

  • Get a plane for a polytope face.

function polytope_face_vcounts (f)

  • List the vertex counts for all polytope faces.

function polytope_face_angles (c, f)

  • List the angles between all adjacent faces of a polyhedron.

function polytope_edge_lengths (c, e)

  • List the edge lengths of a polytope.

function polytope_edge_angles (c, f)

  • List the adjacent edge angles for each polytope vertex.

function polytope_faces_are_regular (c, f, e, d=6)

  • Test if the faces of a polytope are all regular.

function polytope_triangulate_ft (f)

  • Triangulate the faces of a convex polytope using fan triangulation.

function polygod2d_perimeter (c, p)

  • Calculate the perimeter length of a polygon in 2d.

function polygod2d_area (c, p, s=false)

  • Compute the signed area of a polygon in a Euclidean 2d-space.

function polygod3d_area (c, p, n)

  • Compute the area of a polygon in a Euclidean 3d-space.

function polygod2d_centroid (c, p)

  • Compute the center of mass of a polygon in a Euclidean 2d-space.

function polygod2d_is_cw (c, p)

  • Test the vertex ordering of a polygon in a Euclidean 2d-space.

function polygod2d_is_convex (c, p)

  • Test the convexity of a polygon in a Euclidean 2d-space.

function polygod2d_winding (c, p, t)

  • Compute the winding number of a polygon about a point in a Euclidean 2d-space.

function polygod2d_is_pip_wn (c, p, t)

  • Test if a point is inside a polygon in a Euclidean 2d-space using winding number.

function polygod2d_is_pip_as (c, p, t)

  • Test if a point is inside a polygon in a Euclidean 2d-space using angle summation.

function polyhedron_area (c, f)

  • Compute the surface area of a polyhedron in a Euclidean 3d-space.

function polyhedron_volume_tf (c, f)

  • Compute the volume of a triangulated polyhedron in a Euclidean 3d-space.

function polyhedron_centroid_tf (c, f)

  • Compute the center of mass of a triangulated polyhedron in a Euclidean 3d-space.

function linear_extrude_pp2pf (c, p, h=1, centroid=false, center=false)

  • Convert a polygon to a polyhedron by adding a height dimension.

Examples

Numbering

include <omdl-v0.6.1/omdl-base.scad>;
include <omdl-v0.6.1/database/geometry/polyhedra/johnson.scad>;

tc = dtc_polyhedra_johnson;
tr = dtr_polyhedra_johnson;
id = "metagyrate_diminished_rhombicosidodecahedron";

c = get_table_v(tr, tc, id, "c");
f = get_table_v(tr, tc, id, "f");
v = coordinates_csc(c, 100);

polytope_number(v, f, sp=true);

Framing

include <omdl-v0.6.1/omdl-base.scad>;
include <omdl-v0.6.1/database/geometry/polyhedra/cupolas.scad>;

tc = dtc_polyhedra_cupolas;
tr = dtr_polyhedra_cupolas;
id = "pentagonal_cupola";

c = get_table_v(tr, tc, id, "c");
f = get_table_v(tr, tc, id, "f");

v1 = coordinates_csc(c, 100);
v2 = coordinates_csc(c, 100, true);

grid_repeat(2, 225, center=true)
{
  polytope_frame(v1, f) {circle(r=4); color("grey") sphere(r=6);}
  polytope_frame(v2, f) {circle(r=4); color("grey") sphere(r=6);}
}

Shapes on edge, vertex, face

include <omdl-v0.6.1/omdl-base.scad>;
include <omdl-v0.6.1/database/geometry/polyhedra/archimedean.scad>;

tc = dtc_polyhedra_archimedean;
tr = dtr_polyhedra_archimedean;
id = "truncated_cuboctahedron";

c = get_table_v(tr, tc, id, "c");
f = get_table_v(tr, tc, id, "f");
v = coordinates_csc(c, 100);

polytope_frame(v, f, fi="even")
{
  circle(r=2);
  color("grey") sphere(r=4);
  color("red") star3d(20);
}

polytope_frame(v, f, fi="odd", fc=0, vc=-1, ec=-1)
color("blue") star3d(20);

polyhedron(v, f);

The above functions can be found in the thing for omdl.

description.text:
This is my second attempt at a mount for the MKS on a Tevo Tarantula. This pulls the MKS forward away from the frame and to the right so that it's away from the bed. I'm using it with the stock acrylic MKS rig, but I'm sure it will work with anything that has 20mm on center holes.

It is heavily inspired by darknz's MKS Offset Mount (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2076166), but technically not a remix. His requires supports to print, and I couldn't get my supports to happen, so I jumped into Fusion and attempted to make a similar part from scratch.

My first attempt (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2235266) is dimensionally the same as darknz, but it puts the MKS too far to the right for my tastes. So I went back into fusion and made this one instead. I printed with .3mm layer height and 20% infill. I don't think solid infill is necessary, but that choice is yours.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Season layer height and infill to taste. I just used these settings for a quick simple print.

Tips:

Attach the mounts to the acrylic first. Then to the t-track with your t-nuts. The right hand t-nuts are a little challenging to get to, but not too difficult. I did not use the extra acrylic strip that was originally used to pad large acrylic. IF you want to use it, I suggest to do so under the mounts at the t-track and not under the acrylic of the MKS. This will give more clearance for the X stepper motor as it travels up and down. Flipping the Acrylic base 180 degrees clockwise/counterclockwise gives the ability to offset more one way or the other since the holes are drilled off center
Designed in Fusion 360. Added two instances of it to Slic3r and printed both at once. If you can mirror one of the mounts, then I suggest to do that.

description.text:
These dumbbell extender brackets are glued onto dumbbells and allow you to add additional weight to the dumbbell using Olympic barbell "change" plates.
the extender brackets use magnets to hold the additional plates in place

I had a problem that I needed some dumbbells in between the 20 pound and 35 pound ones I own.
I have some small barbell "change" plates and I devised this extender bracket to hold the small plates (1 1/4 , 2 1/2 and 5lb ) plates onto the 20 pound dumbbell

I printed four of these in PLA and they are holding up just fine

Construction

After printing the brackets I inserted two Neodymium magnets into the bracket and glued into place with epoxy.
I then used epoxy to attach the extender to the dumbbells.
Because the dumbbell is iron it had the added advantage of clamping itself in place with the magnets while drying so no external clamps were needed.

I had put two screw holes in the bracket design as I thought I would drill and tap them into the dumbbell, but epoxy on its own has proven to work fine

Operation

I have used these dumbbells with 2 1 1/4, 2 1/2 and 5lbs. effectively extending my dumbbells from 20 pound to 22 1/2, 25 and 30 pounds.
the magnets will safely hold the plates in place, although if you drop them the plate will fall off or the bracket will shear off.
Use at your caution. I would not use these with plates over my face.

Parts list

I bought the magnets from amazon at the link below

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01C5QR4HS/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

they are described as
TAQTON Neodymium Magnets N52 Disc 1.26”D x 0.06”H

Apart from that you just need two part epoxy resin and a set of dumbbells

Design

This was a quick design made in fusion 360.
I took measurements from my dumbbell, plus the size of my chosen magnets and the Olympic barbell plate hole size.

then I just made a simple bracket

Disclaimer

Although I have used these without any accidents. You should use at your own risk. If you clang the dumbbells together of more them jerkily you could unseat the plates which could fall onto you and cause injury.. so use at your own risk

Just tweaked it a little so the handles are separated. (For those like me who have a small printer.)
I give full credit to the creator: Boamartin
Enjoy

Do you have this kind of salt shaker with a metal lid that spills salt all over the counter when you remove the lid? Then THIS is the lid for you! NO MORE MESS when removing the lid. :D

Available in your available colors.

p.s if you print it like it's oriented, you will need to sand it smooth!

I had a use for these.  I'm sure others might.  
They're tweezers for picking up ball bearings.  The file attached is for 1/4" BBs, but you could scale it for other sizes.  The scad file is also attached, but it's not parametrized.

Use whatever settings you like.  But you want the arms to be solid (either just 100% infill or make the wall thickness thick enough that it doesn't try to do infill) because it's faster to just fill them entirely than have the printer try to do a teeny infill.  
You can adjust the finger spacing afterwards by heating the tweezers with a lighter or stove.

title: RRD Full Graphic Smart LCD Controller Mount

description.text:
45 degree mounts for wersy's case RRD Full Graphic Smart LCD Controller
Holes are sized for M5 bolts to 2020 extrusion and M3 bolts to the case.
Included are 3 files for the left and right mount individually as well as a file with them plated together.

title: Nerf Stryfe Brushless Flywheel Cage - Kelly Industries
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A brushless flywheel cage for the Nerf Stryfe, designed for Hobbyking's 2627-3800kV brushless outrunner motors. I use the Afro 30A Mini speed controllers, running a modified version of Simonk. The code for my Teensy 3.2, which should also work on a Teensy LC, is available on the Github repository.

Spinup time is comparable to 180 motors with stock flywheels, and I haven't chronographed it, but with the first wheel version, with an 8mm gap, it averaged 165 fps with Accufake darts. You're free to use and modify my design for non-commercial use, and so I have included the Fusion 360 source files. Here's the Nerfhaven thread if you're interested.

Print the cage and flywheels at 90% or 100% infill. All files are oriented as they are meant to be printed, and the cage requires support material. I used Slic3r, and it was important for the flywheels to be printed with seam position set to random, concentric infill and top/bottom fill, and no supports. I would be worried about PLA getting soft under the motor heat, so would advise PET or ABS. A flywheel installation spacer is optional, though helpful for positioning the flywheels at the right place on the motors.

remixed_from.title: Left handed duplicator 6 blower cooling duct

title: Cooling Fan/Shroud with 5cm Blower and Sensor for Wanhao D6/Ultimate
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Finally as much cooling air flow as you want thanks to the EBM-PAPST RLF35-8/14N blower.
Version 11 M12 with stronger attachments on the left side.
Version 10 M12 has an internal fin to direct more air out of the middle nozzle. This version has three larger nozzles and larger duct volume that extends to the back. To optimize the distance between the nozzles and the heatblock (shown with silicone boot) and air flow to the front turn the heat block as shown by about 25 degree.Thanks to Reflector for exploring the space behind the print head assembly. I was conservative there as I don't want to impede on the print area as I use every mm of it.

Version 6 and 7 have 4 nozzles. Version 7 has areas removed that might not be necessary and to expose the cooling block more to airflow. Otherwise it is the same as Version 6. I used the 4 nozzle version for months without issues so this is a safe bet.

Version 7 M12 5015 may fit other 5cm blowers. Although you may have to shorten the funnel to get it to fit in the available space on the printer.

This is designed to be printed from the bottom up with little support, across the blower entry, the left fixtures and right attachment sites. The nozzles print fine without support with the 4 nozzle version but need support for the three nozzle version,

This shroud will not extend beyond the printer dimensions nor limit the print area. You need 3x 20mm M3 (the original screws), 2x 5mm M3, 2x 10mm M3 and one M3 nut. I just tapped the back hole for the M3 screw to fix the EBM-PAPST RLF35-8/14N Blower in place. Also it snaps into the shroud.

I use a silicone boot and no heating problems at 250C and 100% fan power. Not sure how that would work out without insulation on the heat block.

I printed this in PETG 0.150 mm resolution. ABS will be fine as well. If you print with ABS for extra heat resilience the thread for the probe maybe very tight. Screwing the probe in and out repeatedly before installing the shroud will slowly widen the thread.

M12x1mm screw in mount for a M12 proximity sensor. Same position as in 1bigpig's probe mount http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2081168. Install and setup instructions can be found there. Also included is a M12x1mm nut just because the printer can print it perfectly now.

The probe is the Omron Manufacturer Part #: E2B-M12KN08-WP-B1 2M which is PNP and it works flawlessly with a 7805 to reduce voltage down to 5V and the PNP Configuration.h of the Marlin duplicator 6 firmware. This probe has a working distance of 8mm in a M12 form factor. That translates into about 4-5mm for aluminium it appears.

Screw the probe in so that it is flush with the bottom of the shroud as a starting point. Instead of setting Z offsets I just adjust the probe distance by turning it in the thread. This setup works nicely with a 1mm PEI sheet glued on the build plate. There should be enough space for a 3mm glass plate if anyone uses those.

The fan on the cooling block is a EBM PAPST 414F AXIAL FAN, 40MM, 24VDC - no vibrations anymore.

I added the step file for anyone who wants to try adding other blowers or sensors.
This version is perfect for my purposes for a while so it is unlikely that I will make any additional changes.

Printer:

Monoprice ultimate

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

35

Notes:

PETG, 230C or ABS 240C, fan 70% ( first 5 layers fan 0%)

comments.author: Empiricus

comments.text: Checked out version 10 and 11 today; cool ideas.
comments.author: intinify1976

comments.text: PLA is not advisable for shrouds as it will get soft at only 60C. That is easily reached at the nozzles and in the back were the silicone boot doesn't insulate. PLA is also very stiff maybe difficult to snap in the blower. PETG will hold up to 80C, ABS even better up to 100C. If you just print PLA with no heated bed on it may hold up but if you print ABS with 100C printed Bed PLA will likely sag or disintegrate and crash into the print. Thanks for using the model. Cheers
comments.author: Empiricus

comments.text: Over time PLA will be an issue for sure, for shorter periods and the PLA temps (195c) I am printing, it works fine. I have a different 5015 blower style cooler on here now in PLA, it required less bridging than yours so I printed this first, then yours with this installed (many prints in between) and now once my enclosure arrives tomorrow I will reprint this in ABS while using the pabst and the PLA cooler version for best results.  Well that's my hope anyway, I've never printed anything in ABS yet. I do have, the full MS all metal hotend, so with the factory enclosure I should be good. title: Anet A8 Smooth Rod Bushing Remix

description.text:
If your smooth rods have augured out the holes in the acrylic frame you can use this to fix the problem. You need to take the effected frame parts out and clamp them together so the effected holes are aligned. Ream the effected holes out to 10mm (od of the bushing) and press the bushing into the enlarged holes with the flange facing the inner surfaces of the frame. If the inner diameter is too tight to insert the rod you will need to ream it out to 8mm. Use 2 - 8mm locking collars to secure the rods and the bushings in the frame. This should prevent this from happening in the future.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/dxFLiiwxula

title: MPCNC Dust boot for Makita RT0700CX router

description.text:
Herein lies a dust boot for the Makita RT0700CX or similar diameter router, to take a regular shopvac hose.

The design includes mounting points for the MPCNC tool mount, should you choose to make use of that for further stabilising the router, but it's really just optional (and bolting it on like that makes it more painful to remove, obviously).

I added a skirt to the boot by making bolt holes with a soldering iron, rather than designing holes into the boot. Glue would work just as well for those with more patience :)

See also the mounting bracket design itself:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2235410

The dust boot will fit neatly underneath two of those mounting brackets.

description.text:
This is a mount I've put together to put a Titan Aero and pancake stepper on my UM2 (Ultimaker 2) clone to allow direct drive extrusion.

It uses 2x LM6LUU bearings on stock UM2 rod spacing. This should be a drop in replacement for a stock style carriage. It does reduce print volume by a bit, but I've never used a stock UM2 printhead, so I'm not sure how much vs stock. I'm using this blower fan currently: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2240359 but it limits X axis quite a bit, so I'll be designing a new one with an angled blower fan to let the X-Axis move closer to frame extents.

My current version installed (and in use) in the printer is printed solid in PETG (eSUN). Forgive the crappy pictures, I took them while it was printing parts for my new CoreXY prototype I'm designing now.

title: Duplicator i3 Y Axis Skew Correction

description.text:
If you find that your prints are skewed when they should be square, your X-Y axis may not be perpendicular when looking from the Z direction. This block corrects that skew. It should be attached to the smooth rod locks that come with the printer. This mod, in combination with Z axis braces, sacrifices a few mm in the Y and Z direction to allow all 3 axes to be perpendicular to each other. Once installed, the Y axis belt will be rubbing against itself. Install the Y Bracket Extension to prevent the belts from rubbing each other and also from pulling the carriage plate down in the middle.

Parts required for each block:

  • 4 M3 x 5mm bolts
  • 2 M5 nuts (Nylon Lock Nuts are optional)

Parts required for Y Bracket Extension:

  • 2 M4 x 20mm bolts

Installation Steps:

  1. Detach smooth rod locks from printer and remove them from the smooth rods
  2. Use 2 M3 bolts to attach the correction block to the rod locks. The head of the bolt should not protrude past the face of the correction block.
  3. Place the correction block back onto the smooth rods as shown in the example pictures.
  4. Use 2 M3 bolts and M3 nuts to attach the correction block to the printer frame as shown in the example pictures.
  5. Level and align the smooth rods.

Method to align smooth rods:

Requires:

  • Flat and smooth plate such as a piece of glass or metal
  • Z axis braces similar to https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:921948
  • Square with a wide, flat flange such as a rafter square or a better option: http://www.homedepot.com/p/Husky-Universal-Square-HUS125/203951642
  1. Ensure smooth rod lock bolt and 2 correction block bolts are loose enough to allow shifting.
  2. Move the headed bed to the front of the printer and lightly tighten the 2 correction block bolts
  3. Move the headed bed to the back of the printer and lightly tighten the 2 correction block bolts
  4. Remove heated bed and carriage. Leave the linear bearings on the smooth rods.
  5. Place the smooth plate directly onto the smooth rods.
  6. Press down on each of the 4 corners of the plate, directly above the smooth rod. If there is movement, adjust the height of the correction blocks.
  7. Move the Z axis up
  8. Position the square above the smooth rods and place up against the X axis rods. Ensure that the bottom of the square is firm against the smooth plate or Y axis smooth rods.
  9. Use a piece of paper to test the gap between the square and the 2 X axis rods.
  10. Adjust the Z axis braces until the gap between the square and the 2 X axis rods are the same.
  11. Move the Z axis down
  12. When using a square similar to http://www.homedepot.com/p/Husky-Universal-Square-HUS125/203951642, place one of the shorter legs flat against the X axis rods. The long leg should be running parallel to the Y axis rods.
  13. Slide the correction blocks left or right until the Y axis smooth rods run parallel to the square.
  14. Use calipers to check that the space between the rods are the same along the rods. Check the spacing in the front and back of the printer. If the measurements are within 0.5mm of each other, the rods can be considered aligned.
  15. Recheck and/or reiterate the alignment process for better results.
  16. Ensure all bolts are tightened. Be careful not to strip the rod lock.
  17. Install the Y Bracket Extension to the carriage plate and Y axis belt belt bracket.

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

35%+

Hello, thank you.
The drawer runners I used are by Hafale, but any brand would work.
They are full extension runners so when you slide them out you can open the boxes ok.
Also they are soft close. The benefit of the soft close runners is they ‘lock’ when you close them, which stops the drawers from coming out when you move the units around the Workshop.

comments.author: TheMakerShedNZ

comments.text:
Actually the ones I fitted are 400mm, but 450mm would work well.
The 400mm ones are a tight fit, so while they allow all the lids to open fully to remove tools, on some boxes the lids will not stay open.
So if you want the lids to stay open you would need the 450mm runners.
The 400mm runners meant I could keep the rack/shelving unit to the minimum depth possible, if you went with 450mm then obviously you would end up with another 50mm depth to your rack/shelving unit.

title: Daniel Christiansen Differential Motion Bearing (X1) (No Oil) (SLA)

description.text:
www.npg3d.blogspot.com
https://npg3d.blogspot.com/p/title-intro-radial-heavey-duty-anti.html

These are the .STL files of the first Daniel Christiansen bearing that I made. This is a specialty application design not for use with home 3D Printers. Very difficult and I have not came out with instructions for their assembly at this time. However, I have a tip below.

PLEASE READ BEFORE ANYTHING.

Beware: This is NOT designed for use with your typical FDM printer. I highly recommend not doing anything with these files other than to look at them. The tight dimensions found in this model produce difficult overhangs and the tall skinny towers within the Spacer Rollers are highly susceptible for knocking over. This model was designed with the laser sintering process in mind which provides ample support material and which can be removed as a powder.

Moreover, some of the functional surfaces of the models are slightly oversized in order to attain a snug fit after sanding. Once again, the laser sintering process of nylon creates a different material which is much easier to sand. If these models were to be created on PLA or ABS I am afraid it will be very difficult to sand correctly.

Not only that, but this is an alpha stage design, and also one of my first which I made years ago. This will have many flaws, one being the diameter of certain portions of the spacer rollers being too narrow, and also the main/small screw should have a different thread orientation and the hexagonal hole to be made round to achieve desired effect. I do not have the CAD files to this, so this will remain an alpha stage project FOREVER.

------ Important: I also do not provide instructions for assembly at this time. Only download this right now if you would like to figure something out on your own until I release instructions for assembly. To give you a brief tip, use a rubber band to hold the load rollers and spacer rollers together onto the inner sleeve in the appropriate fashion on one side, allowing the other side to be placed into the outer sleeve and reverse knuckle half sleeves. It is too involved to write about it here at this time.

With that being said, I have made these files available for those who wish to observe them, or those who have access to the appropriate facilities in order to create this bearing.

REQUIRED PARTS:

x2 Outer Sleeve
x2 External Flange
x2 Concentor Collar OR x2 Spokey Collar
x2 Corrugated Ring Placer
x2 Sleeve Knuckle
x2 Small Screw
x2 Main Screw
x7 Load Bearing Roller
x7 Spacer Roller
x1 External Housing
x1 External Housing B ( Sand off the mating squares, they do not work)
x1 Stand Top
x1 Stand Bottom
x1 Inner Sleeve

4-12-2017: Just added some more photos.

remixed_from.author: schrodingers_cat
remixed_from.title: B8 Flight Stick Replica Shift Knob

description.text:
Hi All.

Before I list the build process and parts required please thank http://www.thingiverse.com/schrodingers_cat/about for the original design.

So I started this project because I wanted a modified Microsoft Sidewinder Force Feedback 2 joystick to use with DCS world primarily for rotary wing flight with a more realistic cyclic grip.

I found the original design but it was made for a car gear shift stick and so it didn't allow for the routing of any wires to the buttons and there wasn't anywhere to mount a micro switch for the trigger or the 4-way navigation switch.

I took the original .step file and modified it using Fusion360 so that I could use this cyclic as a joystick.

This is not a complete step by step guide or a how to build but I will put up a few pictures, tips and links to parts so that others can have a go at this project as well.

This is not a print and snap together project, it will require some fine soldering, some glue work and a basic knowledge of hobby level electronics also depending on which joystick you decide to use as a base for this project.

Good luck and please discuss openly in the comments section to help everyone out with ideas and issues.

Parts needed:

  • Print all of the parts from the files provided.
  • 1 x USB button controller for at least 8 buttons, I used http://www.derekspearedesigns.com/32-button-no-matrix-controller.html
  • 3 x Off-On push buttons to fit in a 12mm hole, I used http://www.ebay.com.au/itm/252149687379?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT
  • 1 x 4 way navigation switch (for hat button), I used http://au.element14.com/alps/skquaaa010/navigation-switch-4way/dp/1435773
  • 1 x micro switch without roller, I used http://www.ebay.com.au/itm/5Pcs-AC-125V-1A-Mini-SPDT-Micro-Switch-Long-Hinge-Roller-/262889412358?hash=item3d356e1706:g:U-EAAOSw2gxYwsDm
  • 1 x (11mm dia by 20mm long) spring for the trigger, cut down to suit you preferred trigger pressure.
  • 3 x M3 x 16mm screws (I used hex head as seen in photos), button head will require you to drill the holes out a bit.
  • 1 x M3 x 45mm for the trigger.
  • 1 x M3 Hex nut for the trigger screw
  • 2 x M1.5mm or M2 screws for the micro switch (you could also probably just glue it in position)

You will also need a USB cable to plug the USB controller into you computer if you don't have a spare.

This is a link to the forum which shows you how to beef up the MSFFB2 joystick with a bit more grunt https://forums.eagle.ru/showthread.php?t=125281.

Steps I took for assembly:

  1. Did the MSFFB2 resistor mod and tested to make sure it worked properly.

  2. Pull the original MSFFB2 joystick grip off, cut the wires and pulled them through the base of the joystick and removed the wires along with the electrical connector from the circuit board. (NOTE: doing this will mean that the force feeback motors and powered full time once you plug your joystick into the wall socket, you can mod a switch in to turn the force feedback on and off if you don't want to keep turning the power off at the wall.)

  3. Solder all the wiring onto the buttons, micro switch and navigation switch. Wiring diagrams for the nav switch are found on its website in a .pdf.

  4. Run the wiring through the holes in the joystick and push the 3 buttons into place. If they are loose use some hot glue to hold them.

  5. Add the 1 or 2 pin connectors to the other end of the wires and plug them into the USB controller. Plug the USB controller into your PC and test the buttons before proceeding.

  6. Mount the trigger on the left body with the screw and nut to hold it's position, then fit the spring and spring retention plate. Temp fit the micro switch and check that it depresses when pulling the trigger. Adjust the micro switch position as needed then screw/glue in position. Remove the trigger and spring.

  7. Fit the Nav switch into its position and hold with hot glue.

  8. Now that all of the electronics are installed you can fit the right body (make sure the trigger spring place is installed) and screw the 2 halves together. Then fit the trigger spring and trigger. Test to make sure it all functions to your liking.

  9. Route the wires down through the middle of the joystick and through the base. I drilled a 10mm hole in the back of the base to route the wires out. You may need to loosen the 2 screws in the base of the cyclic to clamp it onto the joystick post.

  10. Connect the wires to the USB controller and install it in the controller box.

That should provide a bit of an idea as to how I went about building this project. If you have any extra questions (which I'm sure many of you will from my vague description haha) please ask in the comments and I will answer when I can unless someone else beats me to it.

Enjoy and look out for a single twist grip throttle collective which I'm working on as well.

Anet A8 modified

Notes:

The print settings aren't crucial so you can use what ever works for your printer and material. I recommend 3 walls with 20% minimum for strength especially if using a force feedback joystick. I used supports for the Left and Right bodies to keep a perfect shape for the button holes.

Sorry for the orientation of the files. Obviously lay them flat on your build plate for printing.

title: 3rd Generation Honda Odyssey Magnetic Vent Mount, er, Mount

description.text:
I love the magnetic dash mount for my phone (Logi Zerotouch) but I hate that it blocks my A/C vent (I live in Florida). I also wanted the phone oriented in a place that was reachable and doesn't block anything else in my dash and didn't require hardware to mount. Yeah, a lot of requirements, no? Well, I finally tinkered around and found that I could clip a mount onto the dashboard trim of my 2009 Odyssey without using hardware and here is the result. It's easy to remove the dashboard trim. Just open the upper glove box and use a trim tool or an electrical tape covered screwdriver to pry the trim from the dash where it meets the dash at the glovebox opening. Then you slide the clip on the back of the mount onto the trim between the navigation screen (or radio depending on your model) and the dash trim and push the dash trim back on. I find that it's not wobbly but if you do, you can put some double side tape on the bottom of the mount to affix it to narrow flat part of the trim on top.

Theoretically this should work on any 2005-2010 Odyssey (3rd generation).

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/8z1904N7y1P

I started playing 5E D&D with my son. He chose a Draconian Sorceror named Smoth for his character. This was mostly just going to be a nice display piece since the value of plastic draconian miniatures is much higher than I realized. It's also good for a lot of other things... trap, objective marker, magic circle, prison, etc.

I designed this in Solid Works. The runes around the hexagon are Thorass font and all the others are some font named in Kanji characters, so I'm not sure what to say it is or where I got it from.
Clip that holds the legs in place when the workmate is folded up.

Knock out the pin that holds the leg in place and remove the broken clip.
Print out the two halves of the new clip.
Spread some glue on the bottom half of the piece including around the hole, insert the rod and push together so both halves align.
When dry fit new clip and re-assemble leg and pin. N.B. Super glue seems to work really well with PLA not sure what would work best with ABS. Two reasons for printing this in two halves.
  • It would have meant a bodge to get the bottom pin correct.
  • I think if the top of the clip is in two independent pieces it has more flexibility and is less likely to break.

comments.text:
Someone made the clip for me on an XYZ brand printer. From other examples, the printing is not the best.
The two parts were not exact mirror images. The holes were not big enough for the rod. I got the parts lined up best I could, and sized the rod with a drill bit gage. It is 15/64". Used this size drill bit to clean up the hole.

description.text:
Nintendo Switch Arcade Cabinet (Laser Cut)

Wanted to try my hand at a mini Nintendo Switch Cabinet for Maker Faire. Mocked this up. Will be iterating while I wait for Maker Faire to arrive :D

Uses 3/16" material. I have been using Elmers Foamboard for my prototypes. It's about ~$3.00 for a 20"x30" board from Target / Walmart and it cuts great on a laser cutter.

May 15th 2017 - v.0.1.5 - Added back brace and front lip to keep Switch in place without having to use kickstand.

June 1st 2017 - v.0.1.6 - Made some areas a little taller to lessen the gaps. Cabinet survived a trip to Megacon 2017.

June 17th 2017 - Added updated SVG with correct DPI. AI file is fine, but SVG was set to wrong DPI causing a 20% size reduction.

description.text:
This is a slightly redesigned Voron Belted Extruder created by RussianCatFood. You can go to the Voron github here: https://github.com/mzbotreprap/VORON . You can use 3mm filament with it or install a bowden tube all the way to the hobbed gear and run 1.75mm filament. What I've changed are the following:

  1. Extended the tightening range of the belt. (now you can compensate for stretched belts)
  2. Added Fillets to the quick release assembly to allow for easier filament changes.
  3. Added small ball end washers for the tension spring bases

Items required to build:
1x MK7/8 Hobbed Gear
1x M5x40 bolt
2x M5 Nuts
2x M3x35mm SHCS
2x M3 steel washers
2x M3 Nyloc nuts
2x springs (0.5" Long, 0.18" OD 0.024" Wire) McMaster Carr P/N: 9657K267
1x GT2 closed loop belt 188mm

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15-0.3mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Use the same settings you would for any Voron part. There are 4 sections that need to be removed that are in place for bridging. The three screw holes and one large piece at the corner of where the extruder gear goes.

You need to print the 2 small washers at 0.15mm layer height. I would recommend you print everything but the main body at 0.15mm to get the radius on all the edges.

comments.text: Great enhancements to a great extruder.  Printed this design and its mirror image for my 2nd extruder.  My belts are tight and the extruder is easier to use.  Thanks!

title: Breech Plug for Nerf Mega Bigshock

description.text:
After ripping out the primary air restriction device, I was left with an unsealed hole in the back of my Mega Bigshock. So I quickly threw together this plug. Figured I should share it. It's a tight fit when printed in ABS, easily sealed up with some glue as you tap it flush into place. I didn't print for any unreal detail levels in my installation example photo because it's a functional part, not a visual part. It's not pretty, but for it's intended use, it's skookum as frig.

Giving you two versions for those who don't want my name on your gun, but just in case you do; there ya go~. Make sure you install it with the hollow part to the OUTSIDE of the gun, and that it is FLUSH, no further, with the breech of the gun.

Thinking about doing some more 3D printed mods specifically for this gun as it's been mostly ignored on the 'verse. Comment any ideas you might have, I'll see what I can whip up!

title: Pen Holder that fits on V6 Extruder Mount

description.text:
i was running into problems with not having enough bed space with ones that hang off the side, so i adapted semsemsem's pen holder to fit where the extruder mounts to.
seems to work quite well from my quick tests.

requires a fair amount of support, and is printed vertical, the same direction it'll be when in use.
the hole in the center is currently 9.7mm which should fit some Pilot Precise Rolling Ball pens.
i'll upload a couple versions with different center holes(they will be labeled with the size), to try to give a better range of fitments.

and since i know people will ask, i use inkscape with the laser plugin to do most of the g-code creation.
you can also load pic's in Cura, and use the layer heights of 0.05 for the top and 0.01 for the bottom, when you import the image. (though this was only working for me on Cura 14.09, and not on 2.40 for some reason, it kept saying it failed to load the image)

Screw down bowden stepper bracket designed specifically around one of mine to ensure a snug fit. This is the same type unit supplied with a Tronxy P802E

All screws are counter sunk. The fit is secure enough that the 2 x M3 mounting screws are optional. I run my printer without the M3 screws just fine and am able to pull the servo out of mount to deal with any filament issues but the holes are there if you prefer wearing a belt with suspenders. It's intended use is to mount it atop of a Lack cabinet for easy of accessibility when loading filament but with some modification to the mounting it could find use in applications other than directly overhead.

Tip for filament change. Heat nozzle up, press the extruder drive release then hand feed a small amount of filament in before withdrawing it back out from the print head. The filament forms a glob that won't easily return back up the heat break.This flushing process will clear and release it making for removal easy.

comments.text: Great idea. I've printed this out and used it. Works great so far. Thanks for the idea of moving the extruder outside the cabinet.

description.text:
A simple chuck that allows you to drill out the center of your blanks by using a standard 3-inch faceplate with a drill chuck on the tailstock. STL included is a single of 4 required, identical jaws.

No more lining things up in the vise for the drill press! Simply take your 3/4" blank and insert or tighten down into the jaws and crank away.

Jaws have two relief bands for pipe clamps, but I haven't seen a need for them yet, as this process is usually on the slowest setting on the lathe. Use your brain when putting something like this on a lathe! Keep those RPMs LOOWWWW.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Take 4 M5 bolts, nuts and optional washers, and tighten three of the four jaws to the faceplate. Insert the blank and tighten the last one down.

You're ready to drill!

123D Design.
Saw a similar product at my local woodworker's shop and decided to make my own off a similar design.

title: D&D; 5e Spell Templates
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wasn't happy with any of the commercially available or printable spell templates for 5e spells and have been needing to brush up on my CAD skills. This is a work in progress of various spell templates, starting with the easiest shapes and I will be adding the more complex shapes (cones) once I get my basic design parameters dialed in.

These are made for a 1" square grid, while you can just rescale for 1.25" or 1.5" grids I do plan on making versions for those sizes so it doesn't make them too thick.

UPDATE-01 I have added cones. There is a 15"+30" version, a 30"-only version, a 60" addon to the 30", along with a 30" + 60" version that I'm pretty sure most people (including myself) can't fit on their bed.

UPDATE-02 It was brought to my attention that the source of all spells in 5e should always be the corner of grid squares and not the center of a square. I'll be adding a new circular template that has a simple crosshair design so you can target it to the corner of a square, but I'm going to also leave the square targeting version since it seems to be how many people prefer to target fireballs.

title: Mavic Back Leg Holder Replacement Part

description.text:
If you crash your mavic pro one of the first parts to break is the holder that attaches the back legs to the enclosure. Not to worry - I designed a new one as my first 3D printing project.

I haven't been able to print the part in one piece with satisfactory quality. But separating into two works well. I glue the barrier piece on with epoxy when the drone is fully reassembled.

I've used the Prusa Slic3r to slice this piece. I use a 0.25mm nozzle and the 0.1mm layer height settings. This helps with the print quality. You need to enable supports obviously.

Print mavicHip.stl with the large circle facing the hotbed. The mavicHipBarrier should be printed with the flat side on the bed obviously.

I've printed these in PLA and PETG. PLA prints better but is a little less robust. I've flown many hours with these parts. They work well.

An added benefit is that these parts will now definitely be the first to break on the next crash, increasing the chances of a quick DIY repair next time around - as I just experienced last weekend ...
